creditline: The Walter H. and Valborg P. Ude Memorial Fund and bequest of Miss Tessie Jones, by exchange
provenance:
?Commissioned by Maurits, Prince of Orange (1567–1625), Stadtholder of Holland and Zeeland [1], The Hague, for his mistress, Margaretha van Mechelen; ?Margaretha van Mechelen (c. 1580–1662), Abspoel Castle, Oegstgeest and The Hague (?until d.1662); by descent to her son Lodewijk of Nassau, lord of Beverweerd, Odijk, and the Lek (?until d. 1665) [2]; by descent to Heer van Beverweerd and his wife, Hester van Foreest; Van Foreest family, Nijenburg Castle, Heiloo (until 1954). [Gallery Nicolaas Beets, Amsterdam, by 1954]. Jacob Theodor Cremer, Duin & Kruidberg, Santpoort, The Netherlands (until d. 1979; Cremer sale, Sotheby's and Mak van Waay, Amsterdam, November 17, 1980, no. 10, for D fl 140, 000 (hammer) to Douwes and Artemis); [Gallery Gebr. Douwes, Amsterdam and the Artemis Group, London, 1980–83; sold to Mia]

[1] Maurits of Nassau became Prince of Orange in 1618. 
[2] Lodewijk of Nassau (1602-1665) was second illegitimate son of Prince Maurits and Margaretha van Mechelen. Maurits, a Calvanist, did not marry Margaretha, a Catholic for religious reasons and because of her lower noble rank; however their relationship was a public secret and the couple had three sons (Willem of Nassau (1601-1627); Maurits (1604–1617) [died of the plague]
text: Esaias van de Velde was one of the pioneers of 17th-century Dutch realism and rarely depicted contemporary events. Here he portrays Prince Maurice, a stadholder of the United Provinces (essentially a governor of Dutch Republic), and the noblewoman Margaretha van Mechelen departing from her family home, Castle Abtspoel, seen in the distance.
title: Courtly Procession before Abspoel Castle
